job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: If you need more money on campus I can only recommend fully.
cons: Only ever pays minimum regardless of financial status

review_title: TA at Cooper Union Summer STEM Program
job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: If the class topic is the field you want to go into, this TA position will give you a sense of whether you're fit to be a manager in the future or not. This program is very hands on, and managing students who have a wide range of skill levels is a great muscle to build if you want to go into management. Past some point, there is no way to prepare for this role and the day to day activities; you just have to be quick on your feet and ready to give constructive criticism or feedback. This role can be emotionally exhausting at times, but in the past they have compensated employees who worked past class-time hours.
cons: You don't have authorship over the work you do there (it belongs to Summer STEM). Therefore, even if you help make a website or build a robot, you can't showcase it on your personal portfolio. The director can be hard to work with and aggressive at times, especially regarding scheduling. They gatekeep opportunities and expect you to live, breathe, sleep summer STEM as a TA.

job_title: Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good, It is ok school
cons: not best but ok, I would not recommend to most but some.

job_title: Technical Assistant in New York, NY
pros: As a working artist in NYC, this is a good part time gig. Flexible hours for part timers, use of facilities, and great co-workers. The school is small, so you end up working with a small amount of students, faculty, and staff. Position is a part of NYC teachers union, good protection. Benefits are good for full-time employees.
cons: Rate of pay is lower than most NYC art schools. It is difficult to have a pay raise, the pay rate changes every 5 years when the union renegotiates the contract. Part timers work 9 months out of the year (college semesters), though this is good if you want summers off. Part timers have to buy into the health insurance, which is usually too much to be worth it.

job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: Very understanding staffs and great work environment
cons: Work intensity can be spontaneous/unexpected

job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Ambassador in New York, NY
pros: small community, friendly office staff
cons: poor communication, lack of training

job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Ambassador in New York, NY
pros: Close community, people know each other well especially the students and faculty
cons: Very poor communication and organization

job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: Has flexibility for classes. Good for learning new schools without the academic pressure.
cons: Often there isn't transparency with flat rate projects, at least within the art school.

review_title: Work-Study at Center for Career Development
job_title: Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
- Only required to meet with directors of the department once a week in the remote setting
- Very flexible work hour schedule as long as they're within Mon-Fri and 9-5
cons: - A lot of busy work and can get redundant

job_title: Chemistry Lab Stockroom Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Fun atmosphere, get work done for school
cons: Weird supervisor, very unprofessional and annoying

job_title: Homework Grader in New York, NY
pros: Grading the underclassmen work is always fun
cons: Can be annoying when they make silly mistakes

job_title: Associate Professor in New York, NY
pros: Super-smart students, great colleagues, small scale, humane relationship, located in the heart of NYC, part of the NYU library consortium, socially engaged, politically conscious environment, diverse student body, soon back to free, strong union
cons: disorganized, personality driven, academic politics (as everywhere)

review_title: Ta review at The Cooper Union
job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
flexible schedule
good connections
growth opportunities inside the workplace
cons: The pay is a little low

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in New York, NY
pros: motivated colleagues, great health and retirement benefits
cons: lacks overall organizational structure, onboarding process, and feedback/promotion structure

review_title: Organization is working towards changing for the better
job_title: Reference Librarian in New York, NY
pros: Great, smart people to work with who listen and work towards improving the work place. Part-timers become a part of the staff union, which is great. Lots of wonderful programming. Student body is passionate and active! There's a very strong movement towards decolonizing the structure of the school. Benefits for full-time faculty cannot be beat!
cons: Union for staff is in need of growth (rumors of union busting by admin were common), people take on too many hats in order to keep costs down - sounds like that can't be avoided right now.

job_title: Media Lab Technician in New York, NY
pros: Very nice supervisors that provide sufficient support to you
cons: Popular position, so slots are limited

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: -you will learn much engineering
cons: -you will only learn engineering for 4 years

job_title: Electronics Lab Supervisor in New York, NY
pros:
The faculty and students make it all worthwhile.  I loved the school and it had and still has my heart.

I retired and they gave me a wonderful sendoff.
cons: Administration is not involved with what really goes on.  I was not backed up as far as any authority goes and one personality conflict was not addressed year after year until I chose to leave a place I loved. One of the 2 best jobs I ever had bu the role of my supervisor, the deans office was always only in a punitive and not supportive role. All my good works was largely ignored by the administration who was rarely there.  The supervisor for all staff was the Dean who was really totally uninvolved.  Great work or minimal work was largely treated the same. My extreme motivation was whittled away year by year so I used reaching retirement age as way to leave .

review_title: Life changing experiences! An awesome, special place.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, brilliant students, caring faculty, great student:teacher ratio, great personalized touch. Inexpensive cafeteria on site in the New York winter with awesome homemade Kosher sandwiches. Cooper Cooler available upon request (It's a secret trademarked rapid can and bottle chiller that's awesome!)
cons: Huge work load, always push to do better and achieve more with less. (Perhaps this is a good thing.) Something strange happens to the new academic building at night. Sort of a transformer with its unusual windows and scaffold... I wish they had more money. They need a really rich couple of donors.

review_title: It used to be good but management in last 10 years  is terrible
job_title: Lab Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: The students make it worth while . .  We have a shiny new building.  It looks nice.
cons: The lack of involvement at the direct level by the administration is terrible,.  They are simple collectors of huge salaries but are not involved with the actual goings on.  There is  no direct support f staff, of which I am one.  The Dean is the supervisor of all staff and is NEVER involved with our daily work needs or problems.  Our supervisor is in fact not involved.

job_title: Assistant Manager in New York, NY
pros: Cooper has a unique history and a lot of passionate employees who care deeply for the institution and its students. This is an interesting place to work and you have a lot of freedom to develop new initiatives and try new things in a creative setting.
cons: The instituting is going through some significant growing pains right now as it reorganizes leadership and staff to better fit the school's mission. Even if you have a lot of great new ideas the chances of getting to act on them are slim as admin work and organizational challenges bog everyone down. I think this will be a great place to work in a few years.

job_title: Computer Center Operator in New York, NY
pros: Working at the computer center is mostly being on call so you usually get a good amount of studying done.  Chris Lent and Bob Hopkins are great people to work with, very knowledgeable and friendly!  You can learn a lot from this job.
cons: Some full time faculty in the computer center are very hard to work with.  They will make working here challenging but this is what you will face in the real world.  Good to gain experience.

job_title: Lab Technician in New York, NY
pros: A number of positions available for part-time work to build a student's experience for their resume, as well as making a few bucks to off-put the insane cost of living in the city.
cons: Pay was mediocre, and hours available were minimal, but not very high intensity. There was a LOT of discourse between the professors of different school and with the administration which stirred a large degree of political drama.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits which is the ONLY pro.
cons: I have been under-paid and not be promoted during my years here even I received my Master's and professional liscense. They just don't value talent people but hire and promote friends...So I found an employer that value my talent and is willing to pay me properly.

review_title: Pros & Cons of working as a CUCC Operator

-Great coworkers

cons:

-Could have a bit more interesting aspects ( more exciting tasks)

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Some of the pros are that there is an open door policy and communication between supervisors and employees. Employees are allowed to express their concerns.
cons: Since Cooper Union is a non-profit, it does not have training budget and employees are exected to learn pretty much on their own.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Working as a teaching assistant gave me the opportunity to get used to working as a mentor to a group of people, as well as making me prepared for any questions or situations that suddenly appeared.
cons: Sometimes, there wasn't much guidance from our superiors, so we had to plan out tasks and schedules on our own.

review_title: Adjunct assistant professor at Cooper Union
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Excellent and very professional faculty and staff.  Diverse and unique student body, with lots of creative energy and close-knit community.
cons: No benefits and few hours available for adjunct faculty.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: The students here are amazing, and I've met some great friends during my time here. The work load can be almost unbearable at times, which is both a pro and a con. They push you to the limit here.
cons:
- heavy work load
- small, so not many resources

review_title: i had a good experience at Cooper Union

job_title: Teacher Assistant in Fort Worth, TX

job_title: Makerspace Operator in New York, NY
